line.token: * @copyright Copyright (c) 2012, Matthias Mullie. All rights reserved.
* This array will hold content of strings and regular expressions that have
* been extracted from the JS source code, so we can reliably match "code",
* without having to worry about potential "code-like" characters inside.
* Init the minify class - optionally, code may be passed along already.
// it's possible to add the source through the constructor as well ;)
* Add a file or straight-up code to be minified.
// bogus "usage" of parameter $data: scrutinizer warns this variable is
// not used (we're using func_get_args instead to support overloading),
// but it still needs to be defined because it makes no sense to have
* Minify the data & (optionally) saves it to a file.
* @param string[optional] $path Path to write the data to.
* Minify & gzip the data & (optionally) saves it to a file.
* @param string[optional] $path Path to write the data to.
* Minify the data & write it to a CacheItemInterface object.
* @param CacheItemInterface $item Cache item to write the data to.
* @return CacheItemInterface Cache item with the minifier data.
* @param string[optional] $path Path to write the data to.
* @param string $data Either a path to a file or the content itself.
// check if the data is a file
* @param string $path The path to save the minified data to.
* Register a pattern to execute against the source content.
* @param string|callable $replacement Replacement value for matched pattern.
// study the pattern, we'll execute it more than once
* We can't "just" run some regular expressions against JavaScript: it's a
* complex language. E.g. having an occurrence of // xyz would be a comment,
* unless it's used within a string. Of you could have something that looks
* like a 'string', but inside a comment.
* The only way to accurately replace these pieces is to traverse the JS one
* character at a time and try to find whatever starts first.
* @param string $content The content to replace patterns in.
// find first match for all patterns
// no need to re-run matches that are still in the part of the
// we'll store the match position as well; that way, we
// don't have to redo all preg_matches after changing only
// the first (we'll still know where those others are)
// if the pattern couldn't be matched, there's no point in
// executing it again in later runs on this same content;
// ignore this one until we reach end of content
// no more matches to find: everything's been processed, break out
// see which of the patterns actually found the first thing (we'll
// only want to execute that one, since we're unsure if what the
// other found was not inside what the first found)
// execute the pattern that matches earliest in the content string
// figure out which part of the string was unmatched; that's the
// part we'll execute the patterns on again next
// move the replaced part to $processed and prepare $content to
// again match batch of patterns against
// first match has been replaced & that content is to be left alone,
// the next matches will start after this replacement, so we should
* This is where a pattern is matched against $content and the matches
* are replaced by their respective value.
* This function will be called plenty of times, where $content will always
* @param string $content Content to match pattern against.
* Strings are a pattern we need to match, in order to ignore potential
* code-like content inside them, but we just want all of the string
* This method will replace all string content with simple STRING#
* placeholder text, so we've rid all strings from characters that may be
* misinterpreted. Original string content will be saved in $this->extracted
* and after doing all other minifying, we can restore the original content
// PHP only supports $this inside anonymous functions since 5.4
// check the second index here, because the first always contains a quote
* Empty strings need no placeholder; they can't be confused for
* But we still needed to match them, for the extraction routine
* to skip over this particular string.
* * Don't count ' or " as end-of-string if it's escaped (has backslash
* * Unless... that backslash itself is escaped (another leading slash),
* in which case it's no longer escaping the ' or "
* * So there can be either no backslash, or an even number
* * multiply all of that times 4, to account for the escaping that has
* to be done to pass the backslash into the PHP string without it being
* considered as escape-char (times 2) and to get it in the regex,
* This method will restore all extracted data (strings, regexes) that were
* replaced with placeholder text in extract*(). The original content was
// nothing was extracted, nothing to restore
* Check if the path is a regular file and can be read.
* Attempts to open file specified by $path for writing.
* @param string $path The path to the file.
* @return resource Specifier for the target file.
'" could not be opened for writing. Check if PHP has enough permissions.'
* Attempts to write $content to the file specified by $handler. $path is used for printing exceptions.
* @param resource $handler The resource to write to.
* @param string $path The path to the file (for exception printing only).
'" could not be written to. Check your disk space and file permissions.'
